You often find yourself wanting to skip the briefings just to get back into the cockpit where the game truly shines. Crucial plot details and character dialogues are  dumped on you in the middle of the most intense, saturated battles. While this aims for immersion, it often has the opposite effect. Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown is an air-combat action game that combines accessible controls with cinematic presentation. Its campaign follows a fictional conflict in the Strangereal universe, using a mix of political tension, personal stories, and high-stakes missions to create a focused narrative backdrop without relying on real-world events.

Flight handling is intentionally stylized. Aircraft respond quickly, maneuvers are exaggerated, and combat emphasizes speed and spectacle rather than simulation accuracy. This design keeps missions intense and readable, allowing players to focus on dogfights, missile evasion, and maintaining momentum. Weather effectsâ€”such as turbulence, icing, and stormsâ€”add situational pressure without overly complicating controls.

The mission variety is strong. Players engage in air superiority battles, ground strikes, defense operations, and large-scale set pieces featuring shifting objectives. The game frequently introduces new threats or environmental conditions to maintain pacing. Enemy ace units and scripted encounters provide standout moments that give the campaign its identity.

Presentation is a major strength. Aircraft models are detailed, the skyboxes are expansive, and particle effects enhance the sense of speed. The soundtrack blends orchestral and electronic elements to match mission tone, and radio chatter contributes constant context during combat.

Progression revolves around unlocking aircraft and weapons through a tech-tree system. This structure encourages replaying missions to earn research points and experiment with different loadouts. Though the system is straightforward, it provides enough depth to support varied playstyles.

Multiplayer includes team deathmatch and battle royaleâ€“style dogfights, offering quick matches focused purely on combat skill. It lacks long-term depth but provides a functional extension of the core mechanics.

Overall, Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown delivers a polished, high-energy air-combat experience built on spectacle, accessible controls, and strong audiovisual design. It is suited for players seeking fast, cinematic aerial action rather than fully realistic flight simulation.

[h1][b]Turbulent[/b][/h1]

Despite years of dormancy, the core experience remains as it always was- lock-on to the green squares and hexagons, turn them red, blow them up. While that doesn't sound electrifying on its own, the gestalt it forms with a bombastic soundtrack and a melodrama-stuffed narrative likewise remains unchanged. That feeling like your flying through an episode of an anime, that certain spark that has left Ace Combat as essentially the last "flight-action" franchise still burns brightly. 

While the core loop is as sound as ever, I can't help but find AC7 unambitious when viewed through a wider lens. Beyond some new cloud and weather tech, courtesy of Unreal Engine 4, AC7 lacks a defining secondary mechanic. There's nothing like commanding a whole squadron in AC5, the branching campaign of ACX, or the choose-your-reputation Ace Style system from AC0. Even the increased scope of battles introduced in AC6 has been pared back to near PS2 levels despite having even more processing power to play with. It seems AC7's rocky development has resulted in it being the most minimalist mainline entry in nearly twenty years and I think it suffers for it. A prevailing sense of creative bankruptcy certainly doesn't help matters. Not only are we starting with bomber attacks and ending with tunnel runs while enemy aces who frustratingly break the laws of physics harder than you and giant superweapons are sandwiched in-between [i]again[/i], levels of self-referentialism have reached the point that we're fighting the [i]same[/i] enemies over the [i]same[/i] locations we did in AC4. After waiting all these years for a new entry in the franchise, I can't help but find what I got safe and underwhelming.  

The narrative also bares some scars. All the parts veterans would expect are there, but they don't seem to mesh quite right- you have an ensemble cast of allies who you're supposed to care about but they feel so thin and anonymous that when they die, no sense of drama or pathos is generated. Even the subordinates (that you can't actually command in any fashion) your eventually granted feel like strangers rather people who hold your life in their hands and vice-versa. You spend a chunk of the game in a Soviet-style penal squadron but this too feels surface level and incidental, nothing meaningful comes of this or your eventual exoneration in terms of the story or gameplay. It all feels coherent and yet [i]off[/i] in a way I don't have the vocabulary for.     

As an aside, I'm not a fan of how aircraft DLC is handled. Buying skins with boosted stats back in AC6 was one thing but paywalling classic, iconic aircraft like the Falken and F-15 S/MTD entirely feels scummy. I'm also not pleased that they're not integrated into the aircraft tree but unceremoniously dumped in your lap immediately, adding pay-to-win to injury.   

As a franchise veteran, I wouldn't recommend Ace Combat 7, at least not before nearly every mainline entire that came before it. The game is [i]fine[/i], but I expect more than that given its pedigree. I'm sure newcomers will find something of merit, though. Especially when the game is on sale.  
 
[b]Pro-Tips[/b]

    [*] Pulse Lasers make things so much easier. Prioritize aircraft that can equip them and parts that enhance them. 
    [*]  Install the Skies Restored mod. Restores cut dialogue while also fixing typos and making other vanilla-friendly improvements. 
[/list]

[h1][b]Turbulent[/b][/h1]

Despite years of dormancy, the core experience remains as it always was- lock-on to the green squares and hexagons, turn them red, blow them up. While that doesn't sound electrifying on its own, the gestalt it forms with a bombastic soundtrack and a melodrama-stuffed narrative likewise remains unchanged. That feeling like your flying through an episode of an anime, that certain spark that has left Ace Combat as essentially the last "flight-action" franchise still burns brightly. 

While the core loop is as sound as ever, I can't help but find AC7 unambitious when viewed through a wider lens. Beyond some new cloud and weather tech, courtesy of Unreal Engine 4, AC7 lacks a defining secondary mechanic. There's nothing like commanding a whole squadron in AC5, the branching campaign of ACX, or the choose-your-reputation Ace Style system from AC0. Even the increased scope of battles introduced in AC6 has been pared back to near PS2 levels despite having even more processing power to play with. It seems AC7's rocky development has resulted in it being the most minimalist mainline entry in nearly twenty years and I think it suffers for it. A prevailing sense of creative bankruptcy certainly doesn't help matters. Not only are we starting with bomber attacks and ending with tunnel runs while enemy aces who frustratingly break the laws of physics harder than you and giant superweapons are sandwiched in-between [i]again[/i], levels of self-referentialism have reached the point that we're fighting the [i]same[/i] enemies over the [i]same[/i] locations we did in AC4. After waiting all these years for a new entry in the franchise, I can't help but find what I got safe and underwhelming.  

The narrative also bares some scars. All the parts veterans would expect are there, but they don't seem to mesh quite right- you have an ensemble cast of allies who you're supposed to care about but they feel so thin and anonymous that when they die, no sense of drama or pathos is generated. Even the subordinates (that you can't actually command in any fashion) your eventually granted feel like strangers rather people who hold your life in their hands and vice-versa. You spend a chunk of the game in a Soviet-style penal squadron but this too feels surface level and incidental, nothing meaningful comes of this or your eventual exoneration in terms of the story or gameplay. It all feels coherent and yet [i]off[/i] in a way I don't have the vocabulary for.     

As an aside, I'm not a fan of how aircraft DLC is handled. Buying skins with boosted stats back in AC6 was one thing but paywalling classic, iconic aircraft like the Falken and F-15 S/MTD entirely feels scummy. I'm also not pleased that they're not integrated into the aircraft tree but unceremoniously dumped in your lap immediately, adding pay-to-win to injury.   

As a franchise veteran, I wouldn't recommend Ace Combat 7, at least not before nearly every mainline entire that came before it. The game is [i]fine[/i], but I expect more than that given its pedigree. I'm sure newcomers will find something of merit, though. Especially when the game is on sale.  
 
[b]Pro-Tips[/b]
[list]
    [*] Pulse Lasers make things so much easier. Prioritize aircraft that can equip them and parts that enhance them. 
    [*]  Install the Skies Restored mod. Restores cut dialogue while also fixing typos and making other vanilla-friendly improvements. 
[/list]

Pros: 
A fun campaign that you might enjoy if you're a fan of the series. 

Cons:
The whole game feels like a watered-down version of Ace Combat Infinity with a Campaign mode slapped on to it.

This has fewer planes than AC Infinity, with some of them being locked behind paywalls.
Which says a metric ton, considering AC Infinity was free to play! 

On top of that, the available parts and planes are not nearly as well-balanced as those of AC Infinity.
AC Infinity also included a PVE game mode, which is completely missing here.

To nobody's surprise, the game also struggles with hackers.
And they are not subtle about it. It's quite obvious that someone is hacking when they have missiles that instantly hit you the moment they fire at you.
This would still be fine if the game had a way to report or at least block these players. But it doesn't.
So if you leave a lobby that's infested with a hacker, don't be surprised if they follow you to a different one (if one is even available). The moment everyone rage quits the lobby they are in.
This was also not an issue on AC Infinity because the game was a PS3 exclusive. But if you're going to have a multiplayer game on PC, you need to account for hackers at least to some capacity.
Instead, the devs decided to stick their heads in the sand and pretend they don't exist while the basement dwellers that use these hacks run rampant and ruin what little is left of the multiplayer community. 

Speaking of AC Infinity, I won't be surprised if all the planes came straight from it because, visually, it looks the same.

Yet, they still managed to create a paid game that's worse in nearly every respect than its free-to-play counterpart when it comes to multiplayer!

If you're buying this for anything other than a simple, fun campaign experience. Don't ... save your money. 
In its current state, this game isn't worth more than $10 at best, and that would be if all the digital content came included.
